docs.snippet: After about 2,400 tests, Dirk Broichhausen, chief executive of GoalControl, has set the bar for success for his company’s goal-line system at perfection....
docs.lead_paragraph: After about 2,400 tests, Dirk Broichhausen, chief executive of GoalControl, has set the bar for success for his company’s goal-line system at perfection.
docs.abstract: Company GoalControl is installing system of cameras and software that will try to ensure, for the first time at a World Cup, that every goal scored has actually crossed the line, and that no ball near the line is incorrectly declared a goal if it has not.

headline.main: With Credibility on Line, World Cup Turns to Technology
headline.print_headline: With Credibility on Line, World Cup Turns to Technology

docs.snippet: FIFA was expected to complete a review of whether Qatar’s successful 2022 World Cup bid was awarded honestly, after complaints led by the British....
docs.lead_paragraph: FIFA was expected to complete a review of whether Qatar’s successful 2022 World Cup bid was awarded honestly, after complaints led by the British.
docs.abstract: FIFA is expected to complete review of whether Qatar's successful 2022 World Cup bid was awarded honestly, and recommend action to soccer federation's judicial body; British critics, who led complaints about bid, say investigation by FIFA's ethics prosecutor was conveniently completed in time to avoid weighing new evidence of corruption, including records showing Qatari billionaire Mohamed bin Hamman essentially bought the 2022 bid.

headline.main: Corruption Claims Cast Cloud on Qatar’s World Cup Bid
headline.print_headline: Corruption Claims and Worker Deaths Cast Cloud Over Another World Cup Host

docs.snippet: Professional soccer is reaching new heights of popularity in the United States, and fans are trying to incorporate foreign traditions without seeming pretentious....
docs.lead_paragraph: Professional soccer is reaching new heights of popularity in the United States, and fans are trying to incorporate foreign traditions without seeming pretentious.
docs.abstract: Professional soccer in America is reaching new heights of popularity on the eve of 2014 World Cup in Brazil; America’s soccer fans have a fighting chance of turning this great world pursuit into an American pastime, and are trying to figure some potentially happy way of incorporating European traditions into a new American fan style.

headline.main: As World Cup Nears, American ‘Football’ Fans Adapt Foreign Traditions

docs.snippet: As the Ed O’Bannon case began on Monday, the N.C.A.A. settled another suit involving the use of college athletes’ likenesses in video games....
docs.lead_paragraph: As the Ed O’Bannon case began on Monday, the N.C.A.A. settled another suit involving the use of college athletes’ likenesses in video games.
docs.abstract: National Collegiate Athletic Assn reaches settlement to pay $20 million to current and former college athletes who sued over the use of their likenesses in video games; players who would most likely receive payments would be men’s basketball and football players who were on rosters of certain teams when the video games were sold; deal comes as higher-profile video game lawsuit, filed by form UCLA basketball star Ed O'Bannon, begins in federal court.

headline.main: N.C.A.A. Settles One Video Game Suit for $20 Million as a Second Begins
headline.print_headline: N.C.A.A. Settles One Video Game Suit for $20 Million as a Second Begins
